timeline.bodyText:
The same handler is used in different threads and its response and contact are set concurrently, so I am afraid that only the result from one node is returned because there is only one response in the handler.
And the answer is still correct because the default replica number and node number are both 3, so timeseries are fully replicated in each node and even if you only query one node, it will have all timeseries. Thus I suggest you test in a different configuration, like 4-node-3-replica or 3-node-2-replica.
timeline.author: jt2594838

replies.bodyText: Yes, there's a problem. Thanks for your reminding. The initialization of handler should be inside each thread.
replies.author: Ring-k

timeline.bodyText:
As nodeListSet is modified in different threads, maybe you should use a concurrent class.
By the way, the naming nodeListSet is confusing, probably better to just use nodeSet.
timeline.author: jt2594838

replies.bodyText: Thanks for your reminding. ConcurrentSkipListSet is used instead of Set now.
replies.author: Ring-k

timeline.message: implement get child path in next level

timeline.bodyText: Why not skip the local node?
timeline.author: jt2594838

replies.bodyText: I thought maybe I can use client == null to check if it is the local node. Since it makes no differentce, I use the if (node.equals(metaGroupMember.getThisNode())) as before.
replies.author: Ring-k

timeline.bodyText: Please notice the concurrent problem as the above one.
timeline.author: jt2594838

timeline.message: send to each group instead of each node

timeline.bodyText: It will be more robust if, for each group, you will try querying each node in the group until one result is returned. So that even if one node is down, you can still get the result from its replicas.
timeline.author: jt2594838

timeline.bodyText:
The current implementation cannot avoid the problem of sending duplicated metadata.
The solution may be modifying the interfaces in MManager to add a filter that will skip the unsatisfying timeseries that do not belong to the slots managed by the member.
It is a little tricky and it is okay if you do it in another PR.
timeline.author: jt2594838

timeline.bodyText: Local groups are the groups that the local node is in and they do not necessarily cover all groups. For example, if replica number is 2, and there are 4 nodes 1,2,3,4 the local groups of 1 will only be [4,1] and [1,2].
timeline.author: jt2594838

replies.bodyText: That's right. Thanks for your reminding.
replies.author: Ring-k

timeline.bodyText: It would be better to leave a log here if you fail to get result from all nodes in the group.
timeline.author: jt2594838

replies.bodyText: Yes, it would be more clear.
replies.author: Ring-k

timeline.message: add log when failed to connect the group
